overview.name: Programme overview
overview.paragraph: The Presidential Employment Stimulus was established in response to the devastating economic impacts of the coronavirus pandemic - but the crisis of unemployment did not start with the pandemic and is not over now. Since its launch in October 2020, the Employment Stimulus has taken public employment programmes (PEPs) and livelihood support interventions to new levels of scale. Its largest programme is the Basic Education Employment Initiative, which places young people as school assistants in over 23,000 schools. It has become South Africa's largest youth employment programme. The contribution of the Presidential Employment Stimulus is not, however, just about the numbers. It's also about the quality of outcomes. Its PEPs are delivering meaningful work experiences - often for participants who have never worked before. For young people in particular, this helps overcome a key barrier to labour market entry. The work undertaken is also delivering real social value. The Employment Stimulus has also provided support to people engaged in livelihood activity and forms of self-employment - including subsistence farmers, Early Childhood Development practitioners, the creative sector and youth enterprises. At present, funding for key programmes in the Presidential Employment Stimulus is confirmed to March 2025.
overview.footer_paragraph: The Presidential Employment Stimulus consolidates data reported by participating departments. This data is subject to ongoing verification and audit by departments. The numbers reported may change based on final verification and audit outcomes. Where work opportunities straddle financial years, the audit process requires that they are reported in both years. For example, Teachers Assistants who start work in February and continue into the next financial year. To avoid 'double counting' of participants, this is corrected under 'total opportunities' reported.

departments.name: Agriculture, Land Reform and Rural Development

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_details.detail: The department received rollovers for unspent funds from Phase One and has issued second vouchers to voucher recipients that qualified. They continue to verify applicants, which requires validating the farmer activity reported. The department faced challenges with certain suppliers that were charging more than the pre-agreed prices for inputs, taking a cut of the vouchers or disbursing cash instead of inputs for production and suspended and blacklisted a number of suppliers on this basis.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_details.detail: DALRRD has overcome a range of challenges in the programme. At one stage, the programme was suspended because of abuse of the voucher scheme by certain private sector suppliers, who were taking a cut of the voucher value. The scheme was re-instated from 15 February 2022 and the voucher validity period was extended. To expedite verification of applicants, a partnership was entered into with the Solidarity Fund, to allow sharing of information. The volume demand for input supplies generated by the scheme is also supporting an expanded supply response in under-serviced areas.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: DALRRD has continued to use roll-over funds to issue vouchers. They are also working with provincial departments and community-based organisation to provide a range of forms of complementary support to farmers, with area-based support groups.

departments.lead: Expanding support to farmers and protecting food value chains
departments.paragraph: The Presidential Employment Stimulus has provided production input vouchers to subsistence farmers. Initially, this was to assist them back into production after the disruptions of Covid. Now, it forms part of ongoing support to expand production activity and returns in this sector.  For the first time, DALRRD used a digital platofrm for the application and allocation of vouchers. This reached every corner of the country, and proved to be both accessible and efficient. Now, DALRRD works with the Provincial departments and NGO's to provide ongoing support to voucher recipients, organised at local level.

departments.name: Basic Education

metrics.name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase I

implementation_detail.programme_name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase I
implementation_detail.detail: The department placed education assistants in schools across the country, exceeding its targets. These young people provided crucial support to teachers in the classroom, they performed administrative tasks and supported maintenance activities. Although Phase 1 was due to conclude at the end of March 2021, most provincial departments were able to extend the education assistants contracts for another month to align with the end of the school term in April. The programme has concluded this Phase. The department has compiled a comprehensive review, that has informed improvements  in Phase Two.

metrics.name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase II

implementation_detail.programme_name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase II
implementation_detail.detail: Phase 2 of the BEEI programme started in November 2021 and continued to March 2022. As DBE wanted to align the programme with the school year (which had not been possible previously) most of these participants continued into Phase 3, from April 2022. To prevent 'double counting' of the number of beneficiaries, this number is removed from the total nuber of beneficiares reported overall in the PES.

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: This programme protected vulnerable teacher posts across the schooling system. Although initially targeted at quintile 4 and 5 schools, where posts supported by parent fees were at risk, the support was targeted to all other schools in recognition of support required in poorer schools as well. This funding support was undersubscribed and so where possible, provinces transferred the funds to support the extension of the school assistants posts by another month.

metrics.name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase III

implementation_detail.programme_name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase III
implementation_detail.detail:
Most of the Phase II school assistants were extended into Phase III for a total ten month placement which they completed in August 2022. Some provinces were able to extend the placement for a limited period beyond that.  DBE placed a strong emphasis on skills development and support for the school assistants, and 150,892 courses were completed by participants. 
NOTE: DBE aligned the programme with the school year, so most school assistants appointed in Phase II during FY 2022 continued into Phase III in FY 2023. Those that continued into FY 2023 are counted here as part of 'current implementation.'  BUT - because they were also part of the completed Phase II - they are subtracted from the overall total performance numbers of the PES to prevent 'double counting' in the overall performance.

metrics.name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase IV (a)

implementation_detail.programme_name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase IV (a)
implementation_detail.detail: Recruitment for Phase IV started from 26 September 2022 on SAYouth.mobi, for placements starting on 1 February 2023, to align with the school year. Over 1,5 million young people applied for the posts on the SAYouth.mobi app with this programme having a siginficant impact in activating young people into the labour market.

metrics.name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase IV

implementation_detail.programme_name: Basic Education Employment Initiative Phase IV
implementation_detail.detail: Recruitment for Phase IV started from 26 September 2022 on SAYouth.mobi, for placements starting on 1 February 2023, to align with the school year. Over 1,5 million young people applied for the posts on the SAYouth.mobi app with this programme having a significant impact in activating young people into the labour market. This phase of the programme mainly ended in September 2023, but a number of provinces used their own resources to extend it.

departments.paragraph: The Basic Education Employment Initiative (BEEI - also known as PYEI-DBE) has at this stage created over 1 million opportunities for young people to be placed as assistants in schools across the country, becoming the largest youth employment programme in South Africa's history. In 2023, it completed its fourth phase.  There are two categories of school assistants. Education Assistants (EAs) support teachers in the classroom. These posts require a matric, with graduates prioritised. General Assistants (GAs) assist with tasks such as school maintenance, security, food gardens and after-school care. The BEEI has provided a new example of how public employment programmes can go rapidly to scale, creating meaningful work at decent standards for young people, while delivering real public value. Surveys illustrate that levels of support from teachers and principals have consistently remained above 93%, with many believing it is strengthening the learning environment at schools. As the programme matures, the scope for it to move the dial on learning outcomes is growing. It has a highly equitable spatial footprint, creating jobs in even the most remote and marginalised communities - because every community has schools.

departments.name: Communications and Digital Technologies

implementation_detail.detail: As a result of delays in impementation, funds were rolled over and implementation envisaged during 2023.

departments.paragraph: The Presidential Employment Stimulus will harness the job-creating potential of digital connectivity by supporting the pilot phase of a Broadband Access Fund as part of Phase 2 of SA Connect. This Fund is developing a well-governed set of technology-agnostic and performance-based capex incentives to extend direct household and public broadband access to low income households. This will leverage private sector capacity to enable last-mile access to affordable, high-quality broadband in areas where providers currently do not have a sufficient incentive to expand coverage. The Broadband Access Fund will provide a “connection subsidy” with conditions related to the quality of connection as well as affordability.

departments.name: Cooperative Governance

implementation_detail.detail: The Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency (MISA) appointed a service provider to deliver capacity development for the use of labour intensive construction methods in 15 municipalities. This included improvements to reporting within EPWP and assisting in project design for the next financial year to incorporate labour intensive methods in infrastructure delivery. This always meant that results would only start to be evident in the new financial year, which in turn meant MISA could not meet the target set in the Phase One timeframe originally given. We are seeing the results now, with MISA starting to report job creation outcomes during the 2022/23 financial year. Capacity support continues and additional municipalities have asked to come on board. This project is having important impacts on the use of labour-intensive methods at municipal level.

MISA worked with municipalities to support seperation at source for recycling purposes. They used a public employment model to raise community awareness which allowed them to build the volumes of waste for recycling - which created the volumes required for small enterprises to collect these for recycling - a nice synergy between public employment and small enterprise development.

The programme started in 16 municipalities in Eastern Cape and KZN, supporting 60 SMMEs and 7,623 work opportunities, to March 2022. It then continued in Mpumalanga, Limpopo and Gauteng, in 7 municipalities, supporting 31 SMEs. MISA has since initiated work in all provinces, in an additional 22 municipalities, supporting a further 24 SMEs. Its impacts on diversion of waste from landfill and on community engagement in recycling has led to increasing demand for participation from municipalities, leading COGTA to augment the programme from its core budgets.

departments.lead: New approaches to solid waste management
departments.paragraph: Through the Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency (MISA), COGTA used the PES to experiment with new ways to tackle the challenge of solid waste. This started with a target of 25 municipalities, 85% of which were rural. But demand from municipalities has seen outreach expand to over 44. The programme supports municipalities to identify collection, sorting and recycling options that divert waste from landfill and explore revenue generation opportunities for community enterprises, by looking at the entire waste value chain, with a focus on community awareness and the circular economy. The programme has also provided support to small enterprises. MISA also continues to support the application of labour-intensive methods in infrastructure in 15 municipalities.

departments.name: Employment and Labour

metrics.name: Employment counseling to facilitate placement of workseekers

implementation_detail.programme_name: Employment counseling to facilitate placement of workseekers
implementation_detail.detail: DEL recruited counselors to support workseekers at its Labour Centres, augmenting its support capacity with strong outcomes.

departments.paragraph: The National Pathway Management Network is an initiative of the Presidential Youth Employment Intervention (PYEI). It brings together many partners in a coordinated system that enables young people to find pathways and successfully transition from learning to earning at scale.  Led by the Department of Employment and Labour, the National Pathway Management Network links young people to opportunities and support, identifies and addresses barriers, and supports the creation of opportunities also. With support from the stimulus, an eco-system manager for the NPMN has been appointed and an associated Innovation Fund has been set up, both through the Jobs Fund. The Department of Labour also supported 215 labour counsellors across various labour centres in the country, to assist employers to clearly specify their job requirements and to build competency profiles that will enable effective placement of work seekers as well as support to upskilling of candidates where necessary. For more information on NPMN, see https://www.stateofthenation.gov.za/presidential-youth-employment-intervention.

departments.name: Forestry, Fisheries and Environment

metrics.name: Cleaning and greening - war on waste with municipalities

implementation_detail.programme_name: Cleaning and greening - war on waste with municipalities
implementation_detail.detail: The programme was not implemented due to procurement challenges.

metrics.name: Department of Fisheries: War on Waste at Harbours and landing sites

implementation_detail.programme_name: Department of Fisheries: War on Waste at Harbours and landing sites
implementation_detail.detail: The programme was not implemented due to procurement challenges.

metrics.name: Oceans and Coast: Source to Sea

implementation_detail.programme_name: Oceans and Coast: Source to Sea
implementation_detail.detail: The programme was not implemented due to procurement challenges.

metrics.name: Groen Sebenzas, weather service - graduate programme

implementation_detail.programme_name: Groen Sebenzas, weather service - graduate programme
implementation_detail.detail: Graduate interns were mentored in natural resource project management and some did fieldwork towards further qualifications in restoration ecology.
The infrastructure in 11 national botanical gardens and 2 zoological gardens was maintained. Eco-champs supported bio-diversity and graduates supported the wildlife economy.
7 facilities in iSimangaliso were maintained and upgraded, 36 kms of fencing was maintained, with roads maintenance undertaken also.
Solar water heaters were installed in Addo, Augrabies, Golden Gate and Tankwa. 33 SMEs were supported to undertake the work, which included 100 small renovations.

metrics.name: Catchment management and strategic water sources

implementation_detail.programme_name: Catchment management and strategic water sources
implementation_detail.detail: The programme focused on the rehabilitation of catchment areas and strategic water resources in protected areas. This involved clearing alien invasive species (which reduce water availability and biodiversity) and limiting bush encroachment (which can reduce grazing capacity by up to 80%). The PES enabled clearing of alien invasive species from 29,414 hectares with follow up cleaning on 141 123 hectares.
Support to 19 traditional authorities on biodiversity, conservation and land rehabilitation was envisaged but faced implementation challenges.

This programme focussed on improving the sustainability of  plantations and indigenous forests and the development of forestry enterprises and also on support to disaster risk reduction in relation to veld and forest fires.
The programme was implemented.
This programme was not implemented

departments.paragraph: The work undertaken in environmental, forestry and fishery programmes touched the length and breadth of the country, from coast to coast, including bushveld, grassland, fynbos, wetlands, mountains, water bodies, catchment areas  – and urban areas, too. The work undertaken affects the air we breathe, the water we drink, the energy we use and the food we eat, supporting a wealth of biodiversity resources and ecological systems essential to life on earth and to the future of the planet.

departments.name: Health

implementation_detail.detail: The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes.
The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes.

The programme concluded at the end of March 2021 and exceeded its target for job creation for nurses. The appointed nurses provided a range of primary health care services in public facilities. Several provinces planned to continue to fund further recruitments to support the roll-out of the COVID-19 vaccination programme.

The department exceeded its target for appointed auxiliary nurses. These nurses supported various services in public health facilities as part of the response to COVID-19. The programme concluded in March 2021.
This programme did not take place.

departments.lead: Primary Health Care at the frontline
departments.paragraph: As the world responded to the COVID-19 pandemic, the critical role that health workers play to enhance the resilience of the national health care system has been foregrounded. The PES has augmented the numbers of health workers, as well as supporting Covid screening services in Port Authorities.

departments.name: Higher Education

metrics.name: PYEI/National Skills Fund: Pay for Performance model for digital skills

implementation_detail.programme_name: PYEI/National Skills Fund: Pay for Performance model for digital skills
implementation_detail.detail: The Request for Proposals for ecosystem facilitators to implement the Pay for Performance model is still pending in the National Skills Fund.
26 universities have come on board and placed young people across a wide range of departments and disciplines. The next phase of recruitment is in process.

metrics.name: PYEI/National Skills Fund: Pay for Performance model for digital skills

implementation_detail.programme_name: PYEI/National Skills Fund: Pay for Performance model for digital skills
implementation_detail.detail: After a significant excercise in building alignment, the 'Jobs Boost Outcomes Fund' was launched in November 2023, with a pay-for-performance model that ensures payment for traiming is only made when young people are placed in quality jobs. This is an important model for building greater alignment between training undertaken and market demand for labour.
In this cycle, 19 universities have placed young graduates in roles that use their qualifications.

departments.lead: Graduate placements in Universities and a 'pay for performance' model for digital skills.
departments.paragraph: DHET is supporting a graduate placement programme in universities - because even for graduates, lack of work experience creates barriers to labour market entry. These placements are for work that allows graduates to apply their skills in relation to their field of study, in order to directly enhance relevant work experience. University departments have been invited to create meaningful opportunities for graduates and in so doing increase their research and academic support capacity.  In addition, in support of the Presidential Youth Employment Intervention (PYEI), and in partnership with the National Skills Fund, DHET is testing a 'pay for performance' model for digital skills training, in which placement in jobs at the end of the training is a critical performance factor.

departments.name: National Treasury

metrics.name: Neighbourhood Development Partnership: PEPS for Metros Programme

implementation_detail.programme_name: Neighbourhood Development Partnership: PEPS for Metros Programme
implementation_detail.detail: While good progress has been made in some metros, others are critically behind in implementation. In addition, many metros have not reported into the EPWP reporting system as agreed, leading to a discrepancy in the numbers they report and those that can be accepted.

metrics.name: Neighbourhood Development Partnership: PEPS for Metros Programme

implementation_detail.programme_name: Neighbourhood Development Partnership: PEPS for Metros Programme
implementation_detail.detail: This programme has overcome a range of challenges to significantly improve performance, with some interesting and innovative programmes in waste, public art, support to homeless people and more.

departments.lead: Innovation in Public Employment Programmes in the Metro's
departments.paragraph: National Treasury’s Neighbourhood Development Partnership Programme opened a grant window for Public Employment Programmes (PEPs) in the metros. This emphasises the creation of meaningful forms of work that respond to community priorities, encouraging partnerships with non-state actors and co-funding from the private sector. Metros have been encouraged to innovate in the forms of work undertaken, to maximise the benefit for participants as well as the social, environmental and/or economic impact. Proposals from eight metros are being supported, with the work undertaken including urban agriculture, placemaking, support to homeless people, waste management solutions, catchment management and more.

departments.name: Public Works and Infrastructure

implementation_details.detail: This programme was quick off the mark and placed graduates into different facilities management and infrastructure management programmes,  exceeding its targets. The department was able to extend contracts for all graduates for an additional five months after the envisaged end in March 2021.

departments.paragraph: In Phase One, unemployed graduates were placed in programmes such as water and energy efficiency, Welisizwe Rural Bridges programme, facilities management, waste management and real estate management within DPWI. The programme exceeded its target and was able to extend contracts for all graduates for an additional five months at the end of Phase One, when the programme concluded.

departments.name: Science and Innovation

implementation_detail.detail: Programme participants were responsible for building social compacts to initiate behaviour change interventions at community level during the Covid-19 pandemic. The programme has concluded.

The programme exceeded the planned target due to the addition of a food garden project that required additional labour. Overall, 20 project sites were implemented with teams working across the catchment area on different environmental interventions in support of river health. A team of young graduates focussed on analysing river health data, and gathered stories from communities to compile a 'State of the River' report, in partnership with Umgeni Water. This has now been completed. All the young graduates on this programme have since transitioned to other jobs, mainly in the sector.

Placement of graduates was affected by university system closures which meant students could not register and provide proof as part of the application process within initial timeframes but these challenges were overcome and the programme implemented.
Aafter initial delays, the programme was able to secure hosts for the graduates, with strongly positive feedback.

The Duzi-Umgeni Conservation Trust built partnerships with 14 organisations, all contributing to creating employment from contributing to river health.  In the context of the recent floods in KZN, the work undertaken was recognised as having mitigated flood damage in certain areas.

In addition to placing graduates in public and private water-related utilities and firms to provide them with work experience, this programme included an entrepreneurship incubator for 300 graduates. Two of these 'Manzipreneurs' made it to the finals of the Climate Launch Pitch Competition in August 2022 and will represent SA at a continental level; one made it to the global competition. In addition, the WRC developed an intensive career planning and coaching programme for 100 graduates from Phase One, many of whom have secured jobs on exit from the programme.
Graduates were placed in public and private facilities where they are able to apply their science-related skills in practice.

departments.paragraph: Through DSI, a range of innovative citizen science programmes have been supported. In the Duzi-uMgeni River Catchment, Enviro-Champs have been empowering communities to monitor – and improve - water quality, building extensive stakeholder partnerships in the process. The Water Research Commission has placed graduates in public and private water entities and has supported 'Manzipreneurs' to start enterprises. The CSIR has placed science graduates in experiential training with the aim of improving the graduation rate for science, technoogy and engineering students and the HSRC supported Health Promotion Agents in communities, in the context of the pandemic. Budgets from the initial allocation were rolled over to the following financial year.

departments.name: Social Development

implementation_detail.detail: The programme was not implemented.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: The ECD Employment Stimulus Relief Fund (ECD ESRF) faced challenges verifying and approving applicants. Provincial departments were required to pause payments to beneficiaries at the end March 2021 as relief funds were only available for the 2020/21 financial year. Due to delays in the approval of applications and transfer of funds to beneficiaries, only 10% had received payments by that time. Payments resumed in October 2021, after rollovers were approved and although the target was not met, the number of awards did increase significantly.

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: Social workers appointed through the programme provided essential social services during the pandemic. When the programme concluded at the end of March 2021, some provinces managed to absorb social workers into permanent positions.
The NDA is partnering with Civil Society Organisations for the programme, which supports community service activities.
The NDA has used roll-over funds to complete implementation, partnering with Civil Society Organisations for the programme, which supports community service activities.

departments.paragraph: The ECD programme aimed to provide a once-off payment to support ECD Centres back on their feet after Covid lockdown, in a context in which the closure of ECD facilities  threatened to set back coverage in this crucial area. Most ECD provision is however informal, but the inclusion of  informal ECD providers in the support package proved extemely challenging, in terms of compliance requirements, despite extensive support from civil society. While the programme did not reach the extent of coverage intended, valuable lessons have been learned that are helping to inform more effective outreach in future. The PES has also supported social workers and the National Development Agency (NDA) is supported to run a community service programme.

departments.name: Sports, Arts and Culture

implementation_detail.detail: The lockdown restrictions and the fact that most facilities were closed led to low demand from National Sports Federations. However, this programme has been able to start implementing now that sporting activity is back to normal, working through SASCOC.

metrics.name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein

implementation_detail.programme_name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein
implementation_detail.detail: ArtbankSA, hosted by the National Museum in Bloemfontein, partnered with Visual Arts Network of South Africa to place emerging artists in arts institutions such as galleries, museums and other arts organisations. They also commissioned artists to produce work. They faced challenges with the commissioned artwork because many artists were informal and contracting them to undertake work posed procurement challenges, with solutions elusive in the tight implementation timeframes. Lessons have however been learned, enabling renewed efforts in the current programme rollout.

metrics.name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory

implementation_detail.programme_name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory
implementation_detail.detail: This project was by the South African Cultural Observatory (SACO), with Harambee as a partner. The purpose of the project was to 'bridge the gap between market-related skills and artistic expression, allowing artists to market their artworks professionally and expand their business opportunities,' and, most importantly, to ensure a sustainable future income. Artists were trained on management and marketing skills by business school graduates, who acted as mentors. The artists attended 9 training sessions on the development of their business plans. They then producecd business plans, which were evaluated by the Nelson Mandela University Business School. Based on feedback, they were supported to implement their business plans, including market targeting, branding, the development of social media platforms for their work.

metrics.name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres

implementation_detail.programme_name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres
implementation_detail.detail: A wide range of provincial entitites were involved in supporting public art. Visual artists were supported  to undertake striking murals in places from Mahikeng to Mdantsane, from Mankweng to Taung, from Rustenburg to Harrismith.  There were poetry readings in schools and drama in community halls, as well as music concerts and dance events. Challenges were experienced with contracting, given that most local artists operate informally. There was insufficient budget for art material costs.

metrics.name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency

implementation_detail.programme_name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency
implementation_detail.detail: The programme appointed young people to conduct audits of approximately 1,600 memorials, monuments and statues around the country.  The programme extended participants for an additional month until end of April 2021 to complete fieldwork.

metrics.name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa

implementation_detail.programme_name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa
implementation_detail.detail: The programme extended the contracts of appointed participants until June 2021 to allow for completion of the work.
The programme was extended until June 2021 and has been crucial in enabling the NARSSA to build capacity on digitisation and seeks to digitise one million records.
This project was completed.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The National Arts Council's (NAC) call for proposals for the sector was hugely oversubscribed, reflecting the scale of need - and opportunity - in the sector. The NAC allocated awards that exceeded the total available funds for the programme. In an attempt to remedy this, awards already made were withdrawn and grant amounts revised downwards, creating much unhappiness for those negatively affected. The NAC instituted an investigation into the PESP management process and a forensic audit has been completed. While certainly, there were regrettable management failures in the proposal approval process, no fraud or theft of funds was found. Meanwhile, implementation resumed, with the NAC exceeding its beneficiary target, with a wide range of inspiring and high-quality work in the sector supported.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The NFVF call for proposals was oversubscribed with a total of 891 applications received that could have created in excess of  48 000 jobs - reflecting the scale of potential for job creation in this sector. Over 200 awards were made, supporting extensive local-content creation in the audio-visual sector, creating work not only for for film-makers and actors, but also for make-up artists, animators, costume designers, sound technicians, the carpenters who build the sets and many more. Production of many of these projects has extended into 2022, with a steady stream of local content arising from the support provided.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support arts and culture practitioners - which were oversubscribed.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support arts and culture practitioners.

metrics.name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust
implementation_detail.detail: The programme was oversubscribed and 65 organisations received support to retain jobs in the sector. The largest component was support to the golf sector to retain the jobs of the caddies.
The District Six Museum in Cape Town was supported to get back on its feet after the shock of the Covid pandemic lockdown.
The Hip Hop Museum in Johannesburg was relaunched in February 2022 - with job creation for researchers, construction workers and designers supported through the PES.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds
Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: In its 4th round of PESP funding, the NAC has supported 637 projects supporting creatives in all the sectors it supports - enabling a proliferation of new creative work in dance, theatre, music, literature and much more

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: In its 4th round of PESP funding, the NFVF has supported a wide variety of projects, including animation, drone photography, documentaries, drama and much, contributing to new levels of local content.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: BASA supports small and micro businesses in the cultural and creative industries. Their call for PESP proposals closed in late September 2023.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: This programme appoints  visual artists to create high-quality art works for the National Museum in Bloemfontein, and also supports proposals for public art installations. The calls for proposals closed in August 2023 - implementation will roll out from early 2024.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

departments.lead: Support to the soul of the nation
departments.paragraph: Through the PES - known as PESP in the sector - a significant scale of stimulus has been provided to the creative and cultural sector. Striking murals have been painted in small towns, records have been digitised in the National Library and National Archives; artists received marketing support; museums and work in the heritage sector have been supported. Now in its fourth phase, the National Arts Council, the National Film and Video Foundation, Business Arts South Africa,  the National Museum and the National Heritage COuncil are supporting a wide range of initiatives, that are supporting many in the sector to create jobs not only for themselves but for others too - while producing art, music, drama, craft, poetry, animations, movies and much more. All of this is supporting creative work at an unprecedented scale, feeding the soul of the nation - with research showing real multiplier effects for jobs and gorwth in the sector, too.

departments.name: Tourism

metrics.name: Support to 40 provincial state-owned tourism attractions

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to 40 provincial state-owned tourism attractions
implementation_detail.detail: The Department of Tourism introduced a range of improvements at state-owned tourism attractions.
The tourism safety monitors contributed to tourist safety during the peak holiday season.

metrics.name: Support to 40 provincial state-owned tourism attractions

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to 40 provincial state-owned tourism attractions
implementation_detail.detail: This programme has been successfully completed.

departments.lead: Tourism monitors and maintenance support to provincial tourism attractions.
departments.paragraph: The Department of Tourism supported maintenance activities in 14 provincial tourism attractions and placed tourism monitors at key tourism sites where extra security enhanced  accessibility for tourists. Budgets allocated in FY 2022 were also applied in FY 2023.

departments.name: Trade, Industry and Competition

implementation_detail.detail: The department exceeded its target for job creation in the global business services sector, facilitated by commitment of additional funds internally to the programme. The support from the employment stimulus concluded at the end of March 2021.
The Industrial Development Corporation appointed 28 Strategic Implementing Partners (SIPs) in this period, with good sectoral and provincial coverage.
The Industrial Development Corporation now has 37 Strategic Implementing Partners (SIPs) in turn supporting over 1,000 community based organisations, with good sectoral and spatial coverage.

departments.lead: Social Employment - work for the common good
departments.paragraph:
President Cyril Ramaphosa has explained the rationale for the Social Employment strategy of the PES: 
‘We are working on the premise that there is no shortage of work to be done to address the many social problems in our society. The aim is to support the considerable creativity, initiative and institutional capabilities that exist in the wider society to engage people in work that serves the common good.’ 
The social employment strategy supports civil society organisations to create employment by building on the work they already do, to enable community-driven solutions to local problems, through supporting 16 hours of work per week. This includes a wide array of activities, including care, Early Childhood Development,combating gender-based violence, community safety, placemaking, river cleaning, support to creative initiatives and much more. This strategy forms part of the dtic's support to the Social and Solidarity Economy. The Industrial Development Corporation is the fund manager. 
In Phase One, the dtic also created opportunities in the call centre industry through its Global Business Services (GBS) incentive programme, and exceeded its target.

departments.name: Transport

implementation_detail.detail: Despite numerous challenges faced by provincial departments in the planning phase, projects were implemented and participants contributed to the maintenance of 4,334 kms of rural roads.

departments.paragraph: Rural roads play a vital role in connecting rural communities to services such as health and education, as well as providing access to markets and economic opportunities. However, rural roads infrastructure remains poor in many areas of South Africa. In Phase One, rural roads programmes were rolled out in most Provinces. Despite numerous challenges faced by provincial departments in the planning phase and implementation, 4,334 kms of roads were maintained.

departments.name: Women, Youth and Persons with Disabilities

implementation_detail.detail: NYDA's target was focused on the number of SMEs supported, but these in turn have created additional jobs.

dimensions.name: Livelihoods supported going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: NYDA successfully delivered support to youth enterprises, exceeding its target.

13 NYS Implementing Partners were appointed, with the Jobs Fund as the fund manager for the programme. Young people undertook community service for a six month period. Their trajectories beyond the programme are being monitored, with positive indicators emerging. See also https://www.stateofthenation.gov.za/presidential-youth-employment-intervention.

The revitalised Youth Service is now in its second phase, now being implemented by the NYDA. Over 14,000 participants from the first phase have transitioned into employment, self-employment and/or education activities.

departments.paragraph: As part of support to the Presidential Youth Employment Intervention, the PES has supported the National Youth Service and the Enterprise Youth Fund. The National Youth Service creates opportunities for young people to contribute meaningfully to their communities and to develop critical skills required to participate effectively in the economy, build confidence and expand their networks and social capital. The Presidential Youth Service program is structured to support service work for 16-hours a week and will channel young people’s energy into advancing social cohesion, nation building and development. It has a strong focus on supporting complementary income-earning opportunities. For more information, see https://www.stateofthenation.gov.za/presidential-youth-employment-intervention.
